description: From Middle English wiglen, probably from Middle Dutch wigelen (“to wiggle”) and perhaps Middle Low German wigelen, frequentative of wiegen (“to rock”), from wiege (“cradle”). See wain, and Dutch wieg (“cradle”).

entries.meaning: A rapid movement in alternating opposite directions, not necessarily regular.
examples: She walked with a sexy wiggle.

verbs.description: wiggle (third-person singular simple present wiggles, present participle wiggling, simple past and past participle wiggled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To move with irregular, back and forward or side to side motions; To shake or jiggle.
examples: Her hips wiggle as she walks.
The jelly wiggles on the plate when you move it.
